This Riparian zone needs more focus;
A riparian zone or riparian area is the interface between land and a river or stream. Riparian is also the proper nomenclature for one of the fifteen terrestrial biomes of the earth. Plant habitats and communities along the river margins and banks are called riparian vegetation, characterized by hydrophilic plants. Riparian zones are important in ecology, environmental management, and civil engineering because of their role in soil conservation, their habitat biodiversity, and the influence they have on fauna and aquatic ecosystems, including grasslands, woodlands, wetlands, or even non-vegetative areas. In some regions the terms riparian woodland, riparian forest, riparian buffer zone, and riparian strip are used to characterize a riparian zone. The word riparian is derived from Latin ripa, meaning river bank.

The author has offered this in response to a comment:

"...this reminds me of something that I now wish I'd made clear in the column: Teachers trust their unions and employers to make sure that good investments are put in front of them. If they're busy educating the nation's children, why on earth would anyone give them a raw deal?"

If anyone "trusts" their union or employer to take care of them, they are in for a rude awakening. Being "too busy" to plan for your own financial future is no excuse. Are all teachers like this?

Mr. Gottfried said to fund a ROTH account thruogh a brokerager account. Makes sense except according to a section on www.pensionrights.org , it seems they might not qualify to do that. http://www.pensionrights.org/publications/fact-sheet/traditional-iras Am I mistaken? Also, one can save much more through a 403b than a self directed IRA or ROTH IRA? Is Mr. Gottfried implying that if one saves $5,500 a year as he recommends on their own, one will have more saved than a teacher who saves $10,000 or more in the 403b? Are thery really that bad? Also, I think you are doing disservice by suggesting one should do it themselves when it comes to investing and saving for retirement. Too many of my friends tried and made so many bad decisions when things got volatile.

Although one can contribute more to a 403(b) than an IRA, the IRA contribution limits are quite high for workers with incomes less than $100,000 a year and many families cannot afford to contribute more to a 403(b) than they would be able to contribute to their IRAs.  There is also the question of whether to use a traditional IRA or a Roth IRA hat was not addressed in the article well.  The Roth IRA contribution is not deductible from one's income and the traditional IRA may be deductible and is for lower income workers as your link noted.  A little known plus of the Roth IRA is that Roth IRA contributions can be withdrawn without penalty or tax at any time.  This is helpful for folks who fear tying up their money until retirement.  They should not withdraw except in an extreme emergency after exhausting their emergency funds.

Just so readers do not miss the distinction: Jim is correct that there is no tax or penalty on withdrawal of Roth CONTRIBUTIONS.  But withdrawal of earnings/growth might or might not be subject to tax and, if you are under 59-1/2, 10% penalty.

Teachers can be like other workers and put their retirement money into IRAs. Unfortunately, many people do not know about IRAs. These accounts are not sponsored by employers and have no match, but many 403(b) and 401(k) plans also have no employer match. A married couple can put up to $11,000 a year ($5,500 each) into IRAs and that would be 15% of their gross income if they earned about $73,000 a year together. Older workers have even higher contribution limits. And they can do this even if they contribute to an employer-sponsored defined contribution (DC) plan like a 401(k) or 403(b).

It's no wonder that statistics by the Investment Company Institute (ici.org) show that there is $7.8 TRILLION in IRAs and just $7.0 trillion in DC plans. One can get the lower fees and choice of passively-managed index funds in one's IRA. But one problem: Many workers are unaware of this choice and think that a 401(k) or 403(b) is the only way to save for retirement.

No, they can't!! People covered by a pension or group retirment plan have restrictions on what they can do according to pensionrights.org

Who can set up a Traditional IRA?

To be eligible for a Traditional IRA, a person must have received earnings from work during the year and be under age 70 ½.

In addition, if an individual participates in a pension, 401(k) or other retirement plan offered by their employer, that person may not be able to contribute to a Traditional Deductible IRA if their income is above certain specified amounts.

For example, if you are covered by a pension, 401(k) or other employer-provided retirement plan, for 2015, you can only take a full tax deduction for your IRA contribution if your earnings for the year are less than $61,000 (or if you are married, if your joint earnings are under $98,000). You can get a partial deduction if your income is less than $71,000 (less than $118,000 if you are married.)

Lots of families have joint earnings (really a modified adjusted gross income) under $98,000 a year, so they should have no problem with getting a deduction for a traditional IRA contribution.  Teachers are usually not well-paid, so there might be many teachers who qualify for a deductible traditional IRA.

There will come a day, if we survive as a species to venture forth from our planet to better assure that survival on other planets, when we first will need to forge a world government and culture where individual countries are mere administrative conveniences. But that day is far off indeed – probably centuries at least. In the meantime, we will have national, parochial interests. During that meantime relative unity will ebb and flow depending on the emergence of great unifiers. No such unifiers have emerged anywhere on Earth for a long time; and Trump certainly isn’t one. Then, he wasn’t summoned to unify the world but merely America.

The wellbeing of the world has permitted some degree of unity in the West for decades; but it was purchased at a significant cost by Americans, in part by defense policy that protected the West while asking too little of our allies; and in part by trade arrangements that excessively favored others. These are significant contributors to the weaknesses that beset our country and the divisiveness that plagues us – as is encroaching automation that soon will affect ALL of humanity.

But the world can’t do with a divided, economically weak and militarily tentative America, not if we are to see relative unity and the peace that comes with it flow again. Trump was summoned to reunify us, make us strong again and in turn allow much of the world to be strong again, too. His “island mentality” is precisely the worldview required to do that.

There already is an international order populated by the very wealthy individuals and corporations. They benefit from the anarchy that results from a focus on national interests.
If Trump was summoned to reunify us, people are going to be disappointed. His political success depends on disunity, class divisions and the spread of animosity toward people who are different.
The US suffered from the Great Recession, as did other industrialized nations. That doesn't imply that the country is no longer "rich," but we have seen that inequality has increased so some of us feel pretty poor. Trump's campaign exploited that feeling, but where is the evidence that his supporters have any interest in unity? And where is the evidence that an "island mentality" will have the desired impact on other countries?

Trump as a unifier?  Maybe, to paraphrase Berchtold Brecht writing about the East German Communist leadership in the early 50's, after it crushed (with Soviet tanks) a popular rebellion, Trump should get other people (rather than the people getting other leaders, which under totalitarianism was not possible).

Although I applaud The New York Times and other legitimate media organizations for standing up to the Trump Administration, I believe the fourth wall can only do so much to convince the public of his sustained campaign to create an alternate reality that only benefits his own twisted agenda. As the legislature is too cowed by Trump, and too concerned with saving their own political necks at the expense of the public (see the House vote against subpoenaing Trump's taxes for further evidence of this behavior), it is up to the judiciary to stand as a counterweight. Let's hope that someone finally sues him to adjudicate the truth.

Given that there is good evidence from a number of different sources to suggest that Trump's closest campaign staff and allies were colluding, or at least coordinating, with Russia to help hack the American election in Trump's favor, I would hope that someone in intelligence circles was monitoring their treasonous activities!

Isn't the fact that during the campaign Trump repeatedly urged the Russian government to hack into former Secretary Hillary Clinton's email server enough to convince voters that he is not only unfit to be president but also a traitor?
